Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that Mexico could adequately protect the applicants from domestic violence and corruption
Application_Facts: Applicants feared persecution by the principal applicant's former husband, a police officer in Mexico
Decision_Outcome: The Board erred in its analysis; the case is remanded for re-hearing
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Court_Ruling: Application allowed; case returned to a new Board for re-determination
Defendant_Behavior: Persecution by former husband who is a police officer, including domestic violence and threats
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of domestic violence and corruption in Mexico
Legal_Standard: Presumption of state protection under subsection 72(1) of IRPA unless rebutted by clear evidence
Assessment_Factor: Effectiveness of state protection in Mexico, particularly regarding domestic violence and corruption
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application under IRPA subsection 72(1)
Evidence_Used: Evidence about ineffective protection measures in Mexico against domestic violence and corruption
Legal_Provision_Cited: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to domestic violence and lack of state protection in Mexico
Evidence_Assessed: Contradictory evidence on Mexicoâ€™s ability to protect victims of domestic violence
Relief_Sought: Grant of refugee protection in Canada
Governing_Rule: Under subsection 72(1) of IRPA, democratic states are presumed to provide adequate protection unless clearly rebutted
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored contradictory evidence about ineffective protection in Mexico
Harm_Assessment: Risk of harm from domestic violence and institutional corruption in Mexico
Cause_Description: Applicants claimed refugee status due to fear of domestic violence and corruption in Mexico
Evidence_Handling: Failure by the Board to properly consider evidence challenging state protection effectiveness
Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient consideration of evidence showing lack of state protection
Legal_Provision: subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: The Board did not adequately assess evidence contradicting the presumption of state protection
Decision_Rationale: The presumption of state protection was applied without sufficient rebuttal analysis despite contrary evidence
Evidentiary_Issues: Overlooked evidence regarding systemic issues in Mexico related to domestic violence and corruption
Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of state protection in democratic countries under IRPA
